Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tropical Waves and Intertropical Convergence Zones in Simulations with Explicit Convection
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project will employ models with explicit convection to study Intertropical Convergence Zones (ITCZ) over the oceans, their interactions with tropical waves, and the dependence of both on convective and mesoscale processes. The primary modeling tool will be the Weather Research and Forecast (WRF) system, which has been augmented to run either as a high-resolution nested tropical channel or as a lower-resolution model with a cloud-resolving model used as a "superparameterization" for convection. This unique model framework allows side-by-side comparisons of simulated ITCZs and convectively coupled waves using standard convection parameterizations, superparameterization, or cloud-resolving horizontal resolution. A suite of idealized cloud-resolving experiments will be performed to test the hypothesis that horizontal mixing by eddies tends to make the ITCZ broader and weaker than it would be in their absence.

Convection-related tropical biases are a major source of error and uncertainty in global atmosphere models, so advances in understanding in this area should lead to improvements in a wide array of weather and climate applications. The project will support the education and training of an atmospheric sciences graduate student. The superparameterized version of the WRF model will eventually be made available to researchers in the broader atmospheric science community. Thus the broader impacts are substantial.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the present day global climate models (also known as general circulation models, or GCMs) are the primary tool for understanding the Earth's climate and how it might be changing with time. The goal of this project was to asses how well such models reproduce precipitation and climate in the tropics, and how they might be improved. For this purpose we compared GCM-type simulations of the tropics in idealized worlds covered in water (aquaplanets) to simulations that use much finer grid spacing ("resolution") that can be presently used for wider research purposes. We did this with a specially designed atmospheric model that uses very fine resolution in the tropics but coarser resolution elsewhere.

By comparing these simulations we identified specific and important biases (erroneous trends) in the GCM-type models. They tend to focus precipitation too closely on the equator, or to split the precipitation into two bands on either side of the equator. These are unrealistic tendencies that are common to many climate models. The simulations with finer grid spacing produce lighter and broader rainfall distributions. Unfortunately, we could not find ways to modify the ordinary model so that it better agreed with the advanced model. The reason is that the finer resolution model more accurately produces squall lines (moving bands of thunderstorms) that propagate across the oceans, distributing the rainfall more broadly into the fringes of the tropics. The standard model framework does not reproduce this behavior.

Within the tropics, precipitation is often focused into large clusters that move eastward with time (against the mean wind in the tropics, which blows from east to west). These are known as Convectively Coupled Kelvin Waves (CCKWs). Using the output from our models, we were able to study the life cycle of these clusters, defined as their developing, mature, and decaying stages. To our knowledge this has not been done before. We found important structural differences in the stages, but more importantly, we understood why the waves tend to end and reform, rather than continuing on forever. The precipitation (thunderstorms) embedded in the wave cannot keep up with the winds and pressure anomalies of the wave, which move faster. Eventually the precipitation falls behind and dissipates, and new storms form ahead of the wave. This is a new way to view these propagating systems in the tropics.
